passages.text: Equity ResearchAugust 28,2025

A clearer picture of the investment base for Pernod Ricard is starting to emerge. Company is focusing on the controllables to drive operating leverage and improving FCF, whilst tweaking the model to emerge stronger for when the downward cycle returns to a growth cycle. With a tricky 1Q in the price, we expect the business to recover from 2Q onwards. As confidence in growth increases, expect shares to re-rate. Cal 2026 PE 16x vs staples 17x.

**What's** **changed?** Given the soft start to 1Q26, we trim F26 org sales to -1.3% (vs -0.7% previously), however keep org EBIT growth unchanged at -1.1%. Q1 will see pressure from inventory adjustments in the US and China and tax headwinds in India. Refreshing for FX (€250m headwind) and scope (€80m), we reduce F26 EPS -1.7%. We roll-forward our DCF by one year and our PT increases to €130.

**Clearer** **picture** **of** **the** **investment** **case** **starting** **to** **emerge.** Earnings are troughing, we expect topline to recover going into 2H, and we see a renewed emphasis on costs, cash and returns after some difficult years.

**Top-line - improvement in F26...Although the business faces near term pressures in China** and the US in Q1, we expect F26 to be better than F25. Although destocking will likely impact US (worth c.-4% to US), group growth improvement is underpinned by: (1) improving trends in GTR (2) no headwind from Russia (3) China decline moderation after a -30% drop from the peak.

...with further improvement from F27 onwards. The growth framework of 3-6% org sales from F27 onwards looks achievable in light of continued strong performance in the majority of markets, and as headwinds in China and US start to ease. The well diversified footprint should provide multiple growth relays, with a change in organisational structure allowing the company to be more nimble in reallocating resources to the most impactful opportunities.

**Bottom line - bootcamp.** Company completed a €900m efficiency program between FY23 and FY25, with +64bps organic operating margin expansion in F25. The additional €1bn efficiency program planned for FY26-FY29, will also help to underpin EBIT delivery, with likely frontloading of savings. -

**Cash and returns.** The F25, company delivered €1.13 billion in FCF (+18% YoY), driven by working capital optimization, and strategic investment discipline. This supported a 74% cash conversion for the year, with company upping this target to 80% for F26. The decision to maintain its dividend at €4.70 per share points to strong cost focus, with disposals likely to help to **reduce** group leverage further.

**Catalyst** **path** **from** **here.** (1) Tariffs: With guidance on EBIT impact reduced to €80m (from €200m), this offers optionality for positive earnings momentum through the year, once there is better visibility on topline dynamics. (2) Top-line: we anticipate topline to improve after the difficult 1Q. An exit rate in 2H of LSD-MSD should provide confidence in the company hitting 3-6% for F27.

In a post- pandemic environment, we see med- term organic revenue growth at the upper end of the \(3\% - 6\%\) range, with fundamentals in mustwin battlegrounds looking healthier. Med- term Europe should deliver \(\mathsf{LSD + }\) growth and Americas \(\mathsf{MSD + }\) In Asia, we believe that Pernod can deliver \(\mathsf{HSD + }\) growth. While sustainable top- line growth is the No. 1 objective at RI, we see a shift towards profitable growth.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
F26E org sales/EBIT- 1.3%/- 1.1% Medium- term revenue growth \(+3\% - 6\%\) with 50- 60bp organic margin expansion p.a. DCF- driven price target of 130

Stronger- than- anticipated performance in key growth engines US, China, India, and Africa driving top- line growth towards \(+7\%\) in the medium term. Upside from cost- cutting if RI closes the "clean" Europe margin gap vs key peer Diageo in Europe. Hidden value from deregulation in India. Potential value- accretive acquisitions. Should the above occur, we see a price target of 160.

Slower growth with extended period of recession. Risk of destocking and downtrading. Pricing climate proves more difficult. FX macro, regulatory risks. Management pursue value- destructive acquisitions. Compression of sector valuations. Should the above occur, we see a price target of 80

Top Material ESG Issue(s): Responsible Drinking. The irresponsible consumption of alcoholic beverages can lead to numerous negative social impacts, which could lead to higher taxes, increased regulation, reputational harm, and a consumer backlash against alcohol. International regulators are calling for spirits companies to take a more active role in discouraging heavy episodic drinking.

Company Target(s): Four Pillars 1) Terror: Regenerative agri schemes in 8 wine regions by 2025, \(100\%\) raw material risk mapped by 2022 with \(100\%\) certification, \(50\%\) reduction in scope 3 by 2030. 2) People: Gender- balanced management by 2030, zero lost time accidents by 2025, training 10,000 bartenders by 2030. 3) Circular. 4) Responsible hosting.

Question 5 to Management: 1) How is ESG integrated into your strategy and management compensation? 2) What is the risk that alcohol follows the route of tobacco from a consumer and regulatory perspective? 3) What is the risk of plain packaging for your business?
Link to ESG Integration Sector Report - here

Given the soft start to 1Q26, we trim F26 ago to \(^{- 1.3\%}\) (vs \(- 0.7\%\) previously), however keep org EBIT growth unchanged at \(- 1.1\%\) . Q1 see pressure from inventory adjustments in the US and China and tax headwinds in India. Refreshing for FX (250m headwind) and scope (80m), we reduce F26 EPS \(- 1.7\%\) . We roll- forward our DCF by one year and our PT increases to €130.
Exhibit 4 - Changes to estimates
Source: Jefferies, Company data F28 Consensus from Visible Alpha

Q1 should see decline, driven by: (1) Distributor inventory adjustments in the US. (2) Soft consumer demand and inventory overhang in China. (3) Excise policy changes in Maharashtra. (4) Cognac sales in China Duty Free resuming only from Q2 onwards. Margins: Commitment to 'defending organic operating margin', supported by: (1) Strict cost control (2) Efficiency initiatives (building on €900m completed in FY25). Cash Generation remains a focus with: (1) Strategic investments below €900m. (2) Targeting cash conversion of \(80\%\) for F26 (versus \(74\%\) in 2025). FX Impact: No specific guidance given, but company guides for this to be significantly negative. We model €250m adverse EBIT impact given strong EUR.

Med term outlook. F27 to F29: Organic net sales growth, average of \(+3\%\) to \(+6\%\) , with organic operating margin expansion. Company to deliver continuing efficiency initiatives resulting in €1bn of savings between F26 and F29, supported by "fit for future" organizational structure. Strategic investments to normalize to €1bn from F26.

The bottom end of the framework \(3\%\) implies that the headwind from weak China and US start to fade, without a major growth contribution from either market. This would appear conservative in our view.
Company aims to maintain A&P spend at \(c.16\%\) of net sales, while preserving agility and responsiveness in allocating resources by brand and market.
We see the following dynamics for F26 by key market.

- USA: Inventory adjustments and subdued consumer sentiment are expected to drive a HSD decline. Of this, half is sell-out and half is attributable to destocking following tariff volatility in F25.- Brazil: HSD growth forecast, driven by strategic international brands gaining share.- Mexico: Performance is expected to be flattish, though the whisky segment continues to gain market share.- Canada: LSD positive growth is likely, supported by strong brand momentum and RTD growth.

- Poland: Trade disputes may limit growth to flat or LSD levels- France: Sales are expected to be flattish, ranging from \(-1\%\) to \(+1\%\) .- Spain: Performance is likely to remain flat, with no major shifts expected similar to France.- Germany: Continued weakness is anticipated, with a HSD decline driven by macroeconomic pressures- UK: A more positive dynamic is emerging, with stable market share and potential for modest growth

- China: A slow start due to inventory overhang and weak demand will likely result in a MSD decline, with some recovery expected in H2 from easier comps. This follows a drop of 1/3rd in the business from peak.- India: Despite strong underlying demand and premiumisation, excise policy changes in Maharashtra could reduce growth to \(+5 - 6\%\) for the year- Turkey: DD growth is expected, led by strong sales of Chivas Regal and Ballantine's- Japan: Mid-to-high single-digit growth is expected, supported by market share gains and strong brand performance- South Korea: The market is bottoming out, with flattish performance expected.- Taiwan: Following three strong years, the market is entering a weak phase with a very negative start to FY26 due to inventory overhang.- South Africa: HSD growth projected, driven by strong performance of Martell and Jameson
- GTR: After a challenging FY25, GTR is expected to return to mid-single-digit growth in FY26, helped by the resumption of Cognac sales in China Duty Free from Q2
Company expects that FX impact is expected to be "significantly negative" in FY26. This is based on current spot rates and ongoing volatility in EM currencies.

In Exhibit 5, we provide a rough estimate of €265 EBIT impact for FY26, we started with company- provided FX rates and impacts for FY24 and FY25. Using this as a baseline, we then introduce current spot rates as a proxy for FY26 and calculated the percentage change from FY25 to FY26 for each currency. By comparing this change to the historical FY25 vs FY24 movement, we extrapolated a ratio that reflects how FX might evolve. This ratio was applied to the known FY25 EBIT impacts to estimate the FY26 effect. The conclusion was a projected FX impact of €265 on FY26 EBIT.
Exhibit 5 - Forecasted FX Impact for FY26 Based on Historical Trends and Spot Rate Projections
Source: Company data, Jefferies

Efficiency Program: €900m Delivered, More to Come: Company completed a €900 million efficiency program between FY23 and FY25, focusing on controllable cost levers. This initiative delivered €600 million in operational savings - through procurement, manufacturing, and supply chain optimization - and €300 million from structural cost reductions, including a \(12\%\) SG&A headcount cut. These efforts led to a +64bps organic operating margin expansion despite a decline in net sales in F25.
Looking ahead, a new €1 billion efficiency program is planned for FY26- FY29 to sustain margin growth and cash generation

Tariff Outlook Sees Improvement: Tariff pressures have eased significantly. Current guidance estimates €80 million annualized impact, down from €200 million previously. This includes €35 million from the U.S. (vs. €60m prior) and €45 million from China (vs. €140m prior), reflecting reduced duties and improved regulatory clarity

In the U.S., distributor inventory levels were elevated at FY25 year- end due to prolonged tariff uncertainty, but adjustments are expected throughout FY26. In China, the resolution of the Cognac suspension in Duty Free and the conclusion of the anti- dumping investigation are expected to restore growth from Q2 onward.
Exhibit 6 - In markets where growth has weakened - such as China - we see the company optimising A&P spend. A&P as % of sales
Source: Jefferies, Company data
Half of the €900m savings programme F23- 25 was delivered in F25. We would expect some front weighting of the F26- 29 programme to help to underpin profit delivery
Exhibit 8 - Despite gross margin pressures, the company has grown margins through strong cost control Operating Margin expansion
Source: Jefferies, Company data
Exhibit 7 - Operational and structural efficiencies resulted in a total of c.900m in savings

Despite a challenging macro, company delivered a \(+2\%\) volume growth in FY25, marking its third consecutive semester of volume recovery. This trend reflects resilience in maintaining momentum across key markets and brands, even as headline net sales declined.

Regional Highlights: (1) India stood out with \(+6\%\) organic net sales growth, driven by strong consumer demand and premiumisation. (2) Canada, Brazil, and Australia posted solid volume growth, gaining market share across core brands such as Jameson, Absolut, and Chivas Regal. (3) Japan saw mid- single- digit growth, while Turkey and South Africa delivered very strong performances.

Brand- Level Momentum: (1) Jameson grew volumes by \(+5\%\) outperforming competitors in several regions and stabilizing in the U.S. with positive Q4 sell- out. (2) Absolut and Chivas Regal also posted volume gains, while RTDs grew \(+7\%\) reflecting strong consumer engagement across formats.
Strategic Implications: This volume recovery, paired with disciplined cost control, reinforces the company's ability to defend margins and sustain growth into FY26.
Exhibit 9 - F25 org sales growth would have been \(+1\%\) ex-US, China and Russia
Source:Jefferies,Company data
Exhibit 10 - Perndog group volumes are \(c.7\%\) above of 1H18 levels
Source:Jefferies,Company data
Exhibit 11 - Future growth more diversified and balanced Organic revenue growth (EURm) per region
Source:Jefferies estimates,Company data
Exhibit 12 - Organic EBIT growth (EURm) per division
Source:Jefferies estimates,Company data
Exhibit 13 - Sales growth by region
Exhibit 15 - Free Cash Flow
Source:Jefferies estimates,Company data
Exhibit 16 - Net Debt/EBITDA
Company anticipates Q1 to be soft, with a decline in organic net sales driven by several converging headwinds across key markets and categories.

Inventory Adjustments: (1) United States: Distributor inventory levels were elevated at the end of FY25 due to prolonged tariff uncertainty. Adjustments are expected to continue throughout FY26, with a pronounced impact in Q1. (2) China: Inventory overhang from Q4 FY25, compounded by weak consumer sentiment and anticipation of the anti- dumping investigation's conclusion, will weigh heavily on Q1.

Regulatory and Tax Headwinds: India: A \(50\%\) excise tax hike in Maharashtra (from \(300\%\) to \(450\%\) ) implemented in July 2025 affects roughly one- third of RSP. This will significantly impact Q1 sales, though medium- term growth remains strong.
Travel Retail (GTR) Disruption: While a resolution is expected in Q2 FY26, Q1 will suffer from the absence of these sales and tough year- over- year comparisons.

Consumer Sentiment: China and the US are experiencing subdued consumer confidence due to macroeconomic pressures and moderation trends. This is affecting frequency of consumption, though intensity per occasion is rising.

Excluding US and China: Positive Growth: When excluding the impact of the US and China, company achieved \(+1\%\) organic net sales growth, underscoring the strength and balance of its global portfolio.

China: Economic Headwinds and Inventory Overhang: China saw a steep \(21\%\) drop in organic net sales in FY25, driven by economic challenges and weak consumer sentiment. Martell and Scotch brands were notably affected, though premium labels like Jameson, Absolut, and Olmeca continued to grow, supported by rising middle- class demand. However, inventory overhang- linked to the pending Anti- Dumping investigation- is expected to cause further declines in Q1 FY26

USA: Soft Consumer Confidence and Tariff Uncertainty. Recorded a \(6\%\) decline in organic net sales, impacted by weak consumer confidence and economic moderation. While the spirits market showed slight growth, Pernod Ricard faced execution challenges. Still, Jameson, Absolut, and Kahlua outperformed peers, with Jameson posting positive Q4 sell- out. A revised Route to Market was introduced, and tariff uncertainty led to year- end inventory issues, with adjustments expected in FY26
Exhibit 17 - Pernod is starting to see early signs of green shoots in USA Pernod volume trend in the US market
Source:Jefferies, NielsenIQ
Exhibit 18 - Pernod US volumes
Source:Jefferies, NielsenIQ

Global Travel Retail: Cognac Suspension and Regional Weakness. GTR posted a \(13\%\) decline in organic net sales, mainly due to the suspension of Cognac imports in China Duty Free and weakness in South Korea and Taiwan. While Europe and the Americas showed growth, Q1 FY26 is expected to be soft, with Q2 likely to rebound as Martell sales resume in China Duty Free. GTR is projected to return to growth in FY26

Strength in Other Markets: Gaining and Holding Share. Despite the challenges in China, USA, and GTR, company demonstrated resilience across many other markets, achieving gains or maintaining market share in 12 of its 17 top markets. Notable performances include:

- India: Organic net sales grew \(+6\%\) driven by strong consumer demand and preimiumisation trends. Strategic brands like Royal Stag and Jameson posted double-digit growth, with Jameson becoming the #1 imported spirit brand in India.- Canada, Brazil, Turkey, South Africa, Australia: All reported market share gains, supported by strong brand performances.- France and Germany: Showed growth and market share gains, while the UK maintained its position.- Japan: Achieved MSD growth, gaining market share despite regional macroeconomic pressures

Excluding US and China: Positive Growth: When excluding the impact of the USA and China, company achieved \(+1\%\) organic net sales growth, underscoring the strength and balance of its global portfolio. This performance reflects the company's ability to navigate volatility and leverage growth opportunities in diverse markets.
Pernod is currently trading at an NTM PE of 16.0x. This sits below 5yr average 20.2x
Exhibit 19 - Shares are currently trading at 16.0x NTM PE, below the 5yr avg of 20.2x
Exhibit 20 - Shares are currently trading at a -20% discount to the staples
Source: Jefferies, FactSet

Pernod is the No. 2 premium spirits company in the world, with sales of €8.8bn in F21. Spirits represent close to \(90\%\) of group sales, where Pernod owns a number of world- leading brands, including Absolut Vodka, Jameson Whiskey, and Martell Cognac. Pernod's portfolio is focused on 14 strategic brands, which include wines and champagnes.
DCF- derived PT. Risks include macro, excise, FX, and regulation.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise PicksJefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
